    Head L (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [15th March, 2000].

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head L of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Wang Kai Yuen].

    Question again proposed.

    The Chairman: Dr Tan Boon Wan is not here. Dr Jennifer Lee.

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Sir, when parents express dissatisfaction with the education system, I expect that part of the problem may lie with the system, but part arises from parents' own response to the system. It seems to me that if we could engage parents in the education process, share information with them about policies and how they work, the reasons for them, the benefits and good outcomes, and the misperceptions and misconceptions that they may have, we could go some way towards gaining the awareness and understanding and alleviating the angst that many parents feel.

Column: 2431



    A good example is information that the Minister shared at the recent sitting that 60% of our school leavers actually make it to our local universities and polytechnics. The implication of 60% making it to tertiary education is that parents do not have to move heaven and earth to try and get their children's performance to the top few percentile and, in fact, fairly average children will be able to make it through tertiary education.

    I do not know how many parents were or even now are aware of that statistic, but certainly information of that nature would give them significant comfort. And I think that we could do more in getting parents involved in this process and give them this kind of understanding.

    In hospitals, we find that time invested upfront in communicating with parents of young patients yields much dividends in gaining their understanding and tolerance and reducing anxiety in the subsequent interactions in the course of their children's care and management. I am acutely aware of the House having just discussed on Wednesday about the burdens of the workload that our teachers face, but I think that time spent with parents explaining policies and sharing information would be well worth the investment. And I hope that the Ministry will be on the look out for opportunities to share useful information with parents and engage them, wherever possible, in the education process.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, we often read in the Straits Times of delinquent school children. While discipline is an age-old problem, it seems from recent reports that disciplinary problems are on the rise.

    At the constituency level, I often receive complaints from residents of students who misbehave themselves outside school. It seems that students and perhaps even some schools operate on the principle that what the students do outside the school is not the concern of the school and should not be within the school's control.

Column: 2432



    As a result, we receive reports of students loitering at the void decks and engaging in such anti-social activities like smoking, littering and vandalism. To be fair, some schools have resorted to ensuring that their students do not engage in such activities by sending members of their staff on patrol in the neighbourhood. I am not sure if all schools have such a practice. On the other hand, it seems that the schools can only intervene in a limited manner, as beyond that I am not sure whether all schools have the practice of checking on the behaviour and conduct of their students. Certainly, when children misbehave themselves, it gives the school a rather bad name. Needless to say, it is imperative that we continue to ensure that our students remain disciplined, as this may impact on our population in the future.

    Sir, I know that the Ministry has a system in place called the behavioural tracking and analysis system that tracks the number of delinquent cases in schools. I would like to ask the Minister whether or not disciplinary problems have been on the rise and what additional measures, if any, the Ministry is going to take in dealing with the problem.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, there have been many reports in the media these days regarding the deterioration of family values. There have been reports of acts of atrocities between teenagers, gang fights amongst teenagers, abandonment of babies by teenagers and so on. I know that families have the responsibility to imbue the right values in their children and to discipline them when necessary. It is acceptable to argue that the teachers in schools can only do so much. However, I would like to beseech the Minister for Education to reassess this area to see how the Ministry of Education could chip in here and nip the problem in the bud before things get out of hand.

    Although the school's main task is to impart skills towards academic achievement, all the efforts will be wasted if moral values deteriorate further. I hope the Ministry of Education will consider the

Column: 2433

teaching and observance of moral and good values in life as an integral part of education. The teachers in schools are in an extremely good position to diagnose early symptoms of delinquency in many cases, as students do spend a lot of time in school. There are many full school days, especially for secondary students, and the teachers are in a lot of contact with their students. The schools should be able to identify at-risk children and either alert their families or any organisation or community.

    Sir, the reason for the deterioration of family values in many instances is due to underlying faults within the family unit or to lack of discipline at homes. These trends may be on the increase with more broken homes and increased divorces. The lack of discipline is compounded by the norm of the dual income families of Singaporeans with two-child families or less. Has the Ministry of Education done any studies on these problematic students thus far, to find out the underlying problems in them? Could the Ministry of Education help those students who are predisposed to these problems and take a more proactive approach to prevent the ill effects?

    Sir, it has been said that every Singaporean counts. This being so and since some kids need more attention than others, would the Ministry of Education not have to allocate more time and effort for these high-risk students? It would be good if the Ministry of Education could collaborate with parents, voluntary welfare organisations, self-help groups and more professional counsellors.

    Sir, may I ask the Minister for Education whether he needs to review the discipline meted out by schools in view of the increased rate of offences committed by secondary school students, especially female school students? Should the schools not use more mentors and role models to lead the pupils? Could the Minister consider self-esteem courses for secondary school students?

    Sir, it will be good to teach children how to empower themselves to succeed in

Column: 2434

life through a correct understanding of one's self worth and through one's core values. A lot of delinquency and gangster issues stem from lack of self esteem. Gangs provide the security and status that the delinquents do not have due to their family situation. Employment of external organisations to facilitate this may be helpful. I know that some schools have engaged outside parties for this purpose. Perhaps this should be put in as a core non-academic curriculum.

    Sir, I hope the Minister for Education could enlighten me on these issues I have raised.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M): Sir, the three Members have raised various issues concerning our students and the role of parents. May I take this opportunity to enlighten Members on some of the efforts undertaken by the Ministry to achieve some of these improvements.

    Firstly, holistic education of a child, we believe, cannot and should not fall squarely on the shoulders of schools. Parents and the community have a role to play. In this case, I agree with both Mr Sin Boon Ann and Dr Lily Neo that we need to get our children to believe in and to practise the good values taught in our schools. Parents and community too help in moulding the child's character, building up his inner motivation, developing a sense of belonging, spirit of service to the community, and also in creating the environment to help the child learn better. The leverage comes from parents, community and schools working in tandem to nurture our young. Also, where one faces constraints, the others can rise to the call and help to address the need.

    There are two main reasons why the Ministry of Education is now stepping up its efforts in strengthening these partnerships. The first is to recapture some of the spirit of community service or gotong royong for schools. This spirit used to come about almost naturally in the past because schools then were mainly set up

Column: 2435

by the community. But today, with education being seen as the responsibility of the Government, there is a need and we must try our best to rekindle the bonding, loyalty and mutual sense of responsibility among schools, parents and community.

    The second is the changing structure of our society and homes. Dr Lily Neo mentioned that in many households, both parents work, and therefore they have less time to interact with their children. Parental expectations have also increased. And this is natural for every parent would want his child to succeed and thrive.

    At MOE, we realise that we need to put in place a framework for schools to engage parents and the community in our children's education, and at a level where there is mutual understanding of the fundamental purpose of education. Every child has talent and ability, and MOE aims to develop to the fullest each child's potential, so that he acquires the values, instincts, attitudes, skills and knowledge to be a useful and responsible individual and citizen. In this respect, we have set up the Community and Parents in Support of Schools (COMPASS). COMPASS is a national advisory council to advise the Ministry on ways and means to promote and strengthen school-home-community collaborations. COMPASS has and will continue to solicit feedback and ideas from parents and the community. It will then develop a common understanding about what are the different roles of the school, the parents and the community in the upbringing as well as the education of our children.

    Already, many of our schools have built up strong traditions and alumni. In 1998, MOE announced that children of former students would be given higher priority for Primary One registration if their parents were also members of the school alumni association. Since then, the number of primary schools with affiliated alumni associations has increased around 50%, from 33 to 48.

Column: 2436



    We also have the School Advisory and Management Committees that give members of the community and parents opportunities to be involved in school governance and its activities. Our schools also conduct meaningful Community Involvement Programmes that help students build up a sense of responsibility, belonging and commitment to the community and country by way of rendering service.
12.45 pm

    The situation now is that there is great diversity in the way our schools, on their own, involve the parents and the community. Some organise seminars for parents while others conduct computer courses for parents as well as for community leaders and they tie up with companies and industries for student work attachment programmes. What works best in a particular school might not meet the needs of another. Therefore, MOE encourages schools to try out their ideas. In doing so, they will go out to reach out to the community and along the process we will gain some experience, and we will build upon it.

    I would like to thank Dr Lily Neo for her suggestion to network with parents and external agencies, especially to help some of our at-risk students. This is what we have been doing and will continue to strive to do even more. Many schools engage the services of part-time professional counsellors, link up with self-help groups, MCD, VWOs, neighbourhood police posts or police centres, work with the Police and Central Narcotics Bureau to conduct talks and programmes. As for mentors, not only do our schools tap on older students and ex-teachers in the school, but also ex-students, tertiary students, parents and other working adults. Many have come forward to help.

    But there is still more that can be done to strengthen the links between parents, the schools and the community . COMPASS is actively encouraging parents and the community to partner schools to bring up our young. Over the past year, COMPASS have visited schools, received

Column: 2437

briefings on programmes in schools, and attended a seminar on school-home collaboration conducted by an expert. These activities gave COMPASS the background and understanding of the issue to work out what we call the stakeholders' statements and the models of effective school-home collaboration.

    The stakeholders' statements are student-centred and outline the roles and qualities we expect of each stakeholder in helping the child to learn and grow. At the heart of these statements is the ultimate aim of achieving the Desired Outcomes of Education. These statements should be ready by sometime next month.

    This year, COMPASS will be formulating various models of effective school-home-community collaborations so that our schools can adopt the good ideas. This should be ready by the end of the year.

    With the efforts of COMPASS, there will be more frequent and higher quality interactions among parents, schools and the community. In this way, we hope we can better align our efforts to develop our young into robust, industrious and morally upright citizens.

    To further encourage partnerships between schools and the community, MOE decided also to take a wider view of our co-curricula activities (CCAs). Previously CCA marks were only awarded for activities offered by schools. From this year, CCA marks are awarded to students in secondary schools for their representation in an approved organisation or for their contribution of at least 30 hours of community service beyond the six hours under the Community Involvement Programme. The scheme has also been extended to junior colleges and centralised institutes. This will encourage our students to widen their social circle and interact with the community beyond the school. We hope to start them young in forging strong links with the community.

    Dr Jennifer Lee will be pleased to note that our schools engage not just the parents but the community in the two areas of communication and partnerships.

Column: 2438

I had described a little bit about partnerships. Now I will discuss a little bit about communications.

    Firstly, our principals and teachers do plan various opportunities like the meet-the-parents sessions, school newsletters, parent-teacher associations, prize-presentation events and these are used to explain changes in our education system. They describe how the school programmes develop our children holistically and discuss the progress of each child.

    On the part of MOE, we ensure that all major changes to the education system and their rationale are also announced through the media and our website. But we also need parents to do their part by attending the school functions, by reading the school newsletters and also hopefully by keeping up with the news.

    Members have also asked about discipline matters in our schools. I would report here that the state of discipline in our schools is generally good. This has been found based on a research done earlier. The great majority of our students are found to be hardworking, well-behaved and responsible. Serious cases of breach of discipline are infrequent occurrences.

    A Committee on the discipline of female pupils was set up sometime in 1998 chaired by Dr Aline Wong. They have looked into the matter and found out that generally there has been some increase, but not alarming. The Committee has also made recommendations ranging from preventive measures such as peer support as well as various other programmes intended to achieve what Members asked for, ie, to nip the problem in the bud.

    Finally, I would like to urge the hon. Members in the House, as leaders in their community, to lead their people to support the schools in their constituencies. We can all treat the children as our own. Get involved in their lives and engage their parents, and involve them in the life of the community. If we can work hand in hand to jointly assume responsibility for

Column: 2439

our young, the Ministry is confident that we will be able to help our young develop to their full capabilities and contribute positively to society.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask whether the Ministry of Education would have any more steps taken to further improve the moral and good values of our students? Secondly, is there any system in place in the school where the teachers are able to actively diagnose high risk students?

    Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M: Other than civic and moral education that is already in place, we also engage students through the Community Involvement Programme. This is where we plan to internalise the concept of good moral values in the children. They visit homes and engage with the homes to do some community service. This will hopefully help them to have good moral values. There are other efforts that we do through the schools to help especially those who are at risk. Thus far, we have trained at least two teachers in every school to become teacher-counsellors. In other words, if a child, through our behavioural tracking system, which is already installed in every school, were found to have some problem and is likely to become a discipline case, he will be referred to the teacher-counsellor. In some schools, we have the Special Constabulary officers who are also helping us to deal with some cases of discipline among our children. So there are such cases. Other than counselling, the school has also the right to impose stricter disciplinary measures if they find it necessary. This will hopefully reduce the incidence.

    Dr Lily Neo: Has the Ministry done any studies on problematic students in Singapore because such studies will help us in planning for the future policies and preventing us from having such children?

    Encik Mohamad Maidin: I do not know whether we can prevent our country from having such children. But it is normal to have in our schools cases of discipline. In fact, hon. Members should not be surprised that in some schools the number

Column: 2440

may increase. What has happened, as had been explained by my Minister earlier, is that our school system is now carrying a lot more students than in the past. What happened previously, especially before we started streaming in 1980, was that many of these children would be outside of the school system. Therefore, they were not captured by our behavioural tracking system or whatever scheme that we have in the schools. What we have done since then is that we want to allow them an opportunity to continue to study. We expect that some of them may come to school with some behavioural problem. The school has a system in place to help them so that they can continue to study and not cause any disruption to other students and, where we can, we will do our best to help them to be more disciplined. Hopefully, with better exposure at secondary school, these children can later on continue with further education.

    I do not think there is a special study just to find out how we can stop children from misbehaving in our schools, but there is a system in place to track them and try to identify them early so as to reduce the problem.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, the published criteria for university admission by the various faculties in NUS and NTU are actually the minimum standard where an application will be considered. However, practically, no student with that level of minimum standards is admitted today. As in the COE system, applicants to the faculties are stack ranked by their "A" level results and then based on the vacancies available, a line is drawn. Those above the line are admitted and those below are not. It is as simple as that. Except for the Medical and Law faculties where interviews are part of the admission process, very little weightage is given to other attributes of the candidate. In fact, for the Faculties of Medicine and Law, where we actually have a limited number of vacancies available, they are turning away candidates who would otherwise be highly sought after in other universities. Notwithstanding my hon. colleague, Dr Jennifer Lee's comment,

Column: 2441

I believe that it is not true that parents are not aware that more than 60% of the cohort is admitted into tertiary education. It is which faculty they get admitted into. I doubt increasing the percentage will help the problem. So long as we have a quota system for the more desirable faculties, the competition for more "As" and the pressure to acquire higher academic result will not go away.

    What we can conclude is that university admission criteria strongly influence the behaviour of our students. No amount of exhortation will change the behaviour if the bottom line is whether they get admitted into the faculty of their choice depends on their "A" level results. I am aware that a tentative step has been taken to include Scholarstic Aptitude Test (SAT) results as an additional criterion for admission into SMU as well as into NUS and NTU.

    I would like to know how would the Ministry prevent this from becoming an additional burden on the students on top of their commitment to "A" level studies. Furthermore, how would that contribute to greater involvement in other co-curricular activities? Perhaps, can we take one step further? Some parents have suggested that if we set the threshold for the number of distinctions that would be considered for admission into the university and that more than this threshold, the additional distinctions will carry no weight, might we be able to change the emphasis on examination results? Perhaps if we put more weightage on co-curricular activities, such as participation in sports, especially participation in a national team, more students might be encouraged to spend time in healthy activities beyond burying their nose in books.

    Sir, on the next subject under university education, I would like to touch on the linkage between the number of student intake of the various faculties and the projection on manpower needs in the economy. In fact, I recall that at the depth of our recent recession in 1998 and 1999, around 9,000 tertiary educated persons were unable to find suitable employment.

Column: 2442

Perhaps by now, this number has dropped to a number that is less worrying. What is disturbing to me is that even in the depth of the recession, we were indeed short of computer professionals, web designers, and other IT professions, and yet, on the other hand, there were graduates unable to find jobs. In other words, we are not just having structural unemployment problems amongst our older workers but also amongst our young graduates. Fortunately, Sir, this state of affairs is only transient, it is temporary. But are there any lessons we can learn from this? At first glance, it would imply that the universities are not adjusting the enrolment mix quick enough to meet the demands of the economy. For many days now in this Chamber, we have heard how the new economy is moving at Internet speed. Yet, for students deciding on their majors, they need to spend three to four years in that particular major before they come out to the job market. Because of this time lag, it is becoming all the more important that forecasting of manpower needs be taken seriously. Sir, I would like to find out from the Ministry how quickly we are adjusting the university enrolment in the face of a fast changing job market.
1.00 pm

    The Chairman: Mr Sinnakruppan is not here. Dr Tan Boon Wan.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, going to university is a major decision. It often means sacrifices and commitment by the students and their families. It is an investment for the future. The students would therefore want to study a course that is useful to help him find a job. To decide on a course, a student would want to know how many Singaporeans are already taking the course. The GPC Chairman (Education), Dr Wang Kai Yuen, has just said, despite the fact that in the depth of recession, some students were unable to find jobs, yet the industries were calling out for graduates of particular disciplines, such as IT, which they required. So there is, in fact, disparity in the demand and supply in the various courses. If students know exactly who are studying what courses, this information

Column: 2443

will allow our people to better allocate their time and resources in pursuing their courses of study. Right now, it appears such information as available is partial, not complete.

    Singaporeans can take three major routes to obtain a university education. They can study in the local universities. They can study at distance learning outfits in Singapore, or they can study in oversea universities. We have information on the local universities. Recently, we obtained information on the number of people studying for university degrees through distance learning outfits in Singapore. We know that there are about 22,800 pursuing their degrees through this route. Many of these long distance learning students are doing business and management courses. What we still lack is information on Singaporeans studying overseas.

    I wonder if it is now time for the Ministry to collect information of our people who are studying overseas, in particular the courses they are studying and the number of students studying them. Besides, this information is also useful for national manpower planning. If we know the amount of manpower we will have in each area or expertise, we can then encourage more to study in areas where manpower is scarce and discourage others from studying in overcrowded areas.

    Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam): Sir, under this cut, I would like to speak on university education for working adults.

    We have heard from the Finance Minister and the Manpower Minister that a key priority of the Government is manpower training. Resources are amply provided to train and upgrade the 850,000 adults, above the age of 40, who have less than secondary education.

    Sir, notwithstanding this, we should not forget and ignore the need of working adults who have received their secondary and post-secondary education and

Column: 2444

wanting to further their studies to obtain their diplomas, degrees and even higher degrees. Continuing education has become necessary and essential to work and live in today's knowledge-based and digital age.

    Sir, I have a brochure here, "Singapore's Snapshot - Facts At A Glance", and there is this heading "Education". Besides describing the two universities and polytechnics, it states:

    "Working adults can enrol in the Open University Degree Programme offered by the Singapore Institute of Management."



    Sir, it is good and right to publicise what we are doing for the working adults. Therefore, I am quite disappointed that the overall expenditure budgeted for the Open University Degree Programme has been cut by 86% for FY2000. Baharudin have all asked what MOE wants to achieve by PSE. I am glad to inform the House that the Steering Committee on PSE, which I chair, has come up with the Desired Outcomes of PSE. It is a comprehensive, yet succinct, list of the end-objectives of PSE and this has been put together in consultation with professionals, practitioners and policy-makers. May I ask the Clerk of Parliament to help me distribute the sheet of paper containing the Desired Outcomes of PSE. [Document distributed to hon. Members.]

    Members will notice that the Desired Outcomes of PSE closely mirrors MOE's desired outcomes of education for the other levels, ie, primary, secondary and JC levels. This is deliberate, so as to ensure a continuity of focus from PSE to primary one. After all, learning is a continuum. As a statement of outcomes reflecting values, attitudes and skills, there is no mention of specific competencies in the 3Rs - reading, writing and arithmetic. Again, this is deliberate, as we want to emphasise that PSE should be about preparing children for life-long learning, and not just a preparation for primary one.

    The current practice of some kindergartens offering parts of the primary one curriculum needs to be re-looked at. I am not saying that we should not teach the 3Rs. Indeed, it is most unnatural to designate the first day of primary one as the beginning of reading, writing and arithmetic education. What I am saying is that there are important pre-reading, pre-writing and pre-arithmetic skills to be learnt before a child can read, write and do sums. We need to give adequate attention to these critical fundamentals. Moreover, a child's motivation and interest in learning must be nurtured from this tender age. We must fire his curiosity and his sense of wonder. He needs to learn in fun ways, through play, art, music and movement. Feeding him with a curriculum that he is not ready for may raise his performance in primary school or at primary one, but this may also dampen his love for learning which will severely affect success in school in the long term.

    The press recently reported the case of one primary school requiring children entering primary one to have already learnt to read and spell about 100 words. I would like to assure the House that this is an extreme case, and that the practice is not widespread. MOE's policy is that schools will take in primary one pupils with varying degrees of readiness and teach them from there. In regular meetings with principals, MOE has reminded schools of this policy.

    The desired outcomes will be translated into a new curriculum which will provide age appropriate learning activities in five domains, ie, moral, cognitive, social, emotional and physical domains. This new curriculum will be ready in about half a year's time. We will teach the children what is right and wrong. Cognitively, children should learn through discovery, experimentation and observation. Language learning will focus on aural, ie, listening, and oral, ie, speaking, skills. Socially, children will learn to listen attentively, share and work together. Emotionally, they will develop self-confidence and be able to relate to others, to their peers and to adults. Activities will also help children develop their physical co-ordination.

    I would like to assure the House that the new curriculum will help to ensure a smooth transition for young children from pre-school to primary one. In designing the curriculum for primary one, MOE will start from the desired outcome "Be able to listen and speak with understanding". There is a language focus in primary one, particularly in English, because this is the medium of instruction and the means by which students access most subjects in the curriculum. Pupils entering primary one do differ in English proficiency, because of their different abilities and backgrounds. For those with basic oral and aural proficiency, the primary one curriculum will build on that. For those with no English facility, schools will focus on the development of the aural and oral skills first, and early reading and writing activities will be gradually phased in.

    Some Members have remarked on the different standards of various PSE centres. I think this is natural, given that the community and private sectors provide PSE, and MOE's regulatory role is in setting guidelines on curriculum and teacher-training. Many people want MOE to bring children to the same starting point at primary one. While this is well-intentioned, in reality, it is impossible. Children have different abilities and aptitudes, and their home backgrounds vary. It is unrealistic to expect that they will turn out the same just because they have been through the same pre-school programme for one or two years. Even students attending exactly the same pre-school class will come to P1 with different levels of preparedness and proficiency. Also, as Mr Sin Boon Ann has put it so eloquently, there will always be parents who try to give their children that extra head-start in PSE over their peers. Children, especially at this age of rapid growth, are different. They develop at different rates and in different ways. We cannot "equalise" everyone after two years of kindergarten. We cannot even do that after 10 years of general education. In fact, as education is about enabling each child to achieve, given his own combination of talents and abilities, it must show up in the end the diverse achievements of people in different areas.

    The PSE can, and should, bring children to an adequate level of school readiness. It cannot, and should not be expected to "equalise" every child by Primary 1. The P1 programme and P1 teachers recognise that pupils are different and they will adapt strategies that are appropriate for them. Actually, our schools already have programmes that cater to these differences. For example, the Learning Support Programme is designed to help P1 and P2 children who have not yet attained a sufficient level of English proficiency to improve quickly. This programme has proven to be successful and has greatly helped the children improve their reading and writing skills.

    To recap, school readiness is not about mastering some of the P1 curriculum by

Column: 2485

day one in primary school. It is also more than having adequate language facility, important though it is. School readiness is about being eager to learn, able to make friends, take turns and share, pay attention, and enjoy learning.

    Members have rightly identified teacher quality as the key to raising the quality of PSE. This point has been raised by Mr Iswaran and Mr Loh Meng See. My Steering Committee on PSE has set up a task force comprising MOE officials and representatives from NIE and other service providers in order to study the matter. It will look into the teacher-training curriculum for different levels of qualification, as well as an accreditation framework, and map out progression routes for PSE teachers to attain higher qualifications. The task force will also study how PSE teachers can participate in continual education and training in order to develop better practice and keep abreast of professional developments in their field. At present, there are a number of agencies providing PSE teacher-training. The task force is looking into how MOE can assure standards and rationalise the provision of teacher training among such agencies.

    As for research, I have earlier explained the need to establish the long-term value of PSE. I also made a case for carefully determining the optimal investment in PSE, should it be shown that it plays a significant part in raising the overall capacity of our people. MOE intends to achieve the above through a pilot research programme. This is a longitudinal study to ascertain the long term cognitive and non-cognitive benefits of PSE. In particular, we will be studying the impact of teacher-training and a new curriculum on children's intellectual and social growth.

    Full details of the pilot research, such as the number of children involved, participating centres, research methodology and funding will be announced later. The pilot research will yield useful insights into the training of teachers and the development of instructional materials. The aim is to see how we can raise the quality of PSE in Singapore, and what level of

Column: 2486

Government investment is justifiable. A full research programme with longitudinal studies indicating the effects of different pre-school strategies is likely to take many years, perhaps up to seven. MOE will carry out a pilot study, and is prepared to proceed on a wider scale on the basis of the preliminary results of this study after two to three years, if the preliminary results indicate that longer term results are likely to be good.

    Before I end, I want to emphasise that MOE will not take over PSE. The provision of PSE will remain firmly in the hands of the private and people sectors. There is merit in allowing different centres with different philosophies and schools of thought to offer different types of PSE. If we look at the range of opinions offered by the press interviews just two days ago, some parents do not want the Government to step in at all. They want choice. They want variety.     I would urge parents to work hand in hand with the centres, and later on with schools, to provide the best learning opportunities and experience for their children. It must be remembered that PSE is only one factor of success in learning. Home support for children is equally, if not more, important.

    First, to give our children a common core of knowledge and skills, which will provide a strong foundation for further education and training that would prepare our children for a knowledge-based economy.

    Second, to give our children a common educational experience which will help build national identity and social cohesion.

In deciding on whether or not compulsory education should be introduced and the form and

Column: 2488

duration by which it should take place, we must constantly bear in mind these two major objectives, which are the reasons why MOE has done its best to bring most children into our national school system.

involved in the development of the selection criteria. They will also be involved in the training of teachers, and may act as advisers to schools.

society. Hence, the negative perception regarding ITE training should be changed and this job should not be left to the Government alone. All of us must play our part.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Peter Chen): Sir, I would like to thank Dr Wang and Dr Tan for their interest in Technical Education.

The concern about ITE's image is understandable, given that the number of students entering ITE constitutes a significant 25% of each cohort.

    Dr Wang believes that technical education deserves a much higher profile and reputation, an image that people should have in their mind. I fully agree with him and I would substantiate this point.

    Since the establishment of ITE in 1992, concerted efforts have been made to improve the public perception and image of ITE. There are many parties to thank for. Firstly, the Government has invested, on average, $170 million a year over the past five years in ITE to expand campuses and build modern facilities. ITE students now study in a conducive environment and have access to the latest high-tech equipment and information technology.

    Secondly, the quality of teaching has improved. The care and concern shown by ITE teachers have helped boost students' self-esteem, confidence and motivation.

    Thirdly, the media has been most supportive of ITE. In 1999 alone, there were 284 favourable mentions in media coverage in the form of press reports, TV exposures and radio broadcasts. This is a 21% increase over 1998.

    As more and more ITE graduates make some headlines with their successes, ITE has found it useful to consolidate these success stories as an encouragement to staff, students and parents. I have given to Members of the House here a copy of an annual publication by ITE titled "I did it my way" [indicating]. The title is reminiscent of the well-known song by Frank Sinatra, but it has a ring of confidence and a

certain pride in it. The current publication features 23 ITE alumni who are now successful professionals or entrepreneurs and also those who have excelled in the pursuit of further studies in polytechnics and universities. But there are also many who are academically inclined - they may develop this trait a bit later than others. About 15% of ITE students move on to polytechnics and 2% go on to complete their university education. The statistics also suggest that ITE graduates who go on to polytechnics are likely to do well there. Generally, they achieve a higher pass rate than other non-ITE graduates and in most instances, the pass rate was 100%. Also, a higher

Column: 2493

percentage of them achieve Diplomas with Merit, as compared to non-ITE graduates.

I would like to stress that ITE has always made it a point to stay relevant to the needs and development of the economy by regularly reviewing its curriculum and programmes. Employability skills such as communication skills, mathematics, IT, industrial studies and social studies are taught to ensure that students will be able to cope with demands beyond their own areas of specialisation. ITE has also introduced four courses during the last two years in response to the growth in IT and chemical process industries.

    However, we must recognise that with the rapid pace of technological developments, knowledge and skills will become obsolete very quickly. The only way to ensure skills relevance is through training and retraining. In this regard, ITE will gear up in terms of training capacity and programmes so that more ITE graduates and the workforce in general can upgrade and renew their skills to remain employable.

    Sir, ITE's intake comprises mainly three levels of students from secondary schools: first, the Normal (Technical), Normal (Academic) as well as the `O' levels. Dr Tan has specifically asked about the performance of the Normal (Technical) stream students.

    If Members recall, the Normal (Technical) course was introduced in 1994 to allow the more practice-oriented students to go through 10 years of general education, before undergoing technical training. To ensure that these students can learn at a comfortable pace, they were given a different curriculum which focused on the teaching of English Language and Mathematics and a practical, hands-on approach in learning, so as to prepare them for a technical education at ITE.

    We have made significant progress in achieving these objectives. Since the

Column: 2494

introduction of the Normal (Technical) stream course, an additional 10% of the Primary 1 cohort has completed 10 years of education. The first three cohorts of Normal (Technical) stream students have completed their secondary education.

    This has provided them with the necessary foundation in language and mathematics for a technical education in ITE. Three quarters or more of the Normal (Technical) pool of students are enrolled in ITE each year. ITE will continue to encourage even more to enrol.

    I am pleased to report that our Normal (Technical) students have done well in their ITE training. Of the 4,033 Normal (Technical) stream students who have enrolled for full-time ITE training in January 1998, 2,204 have graduated with NTC-2 qualifications and 1,013 with Certificates in Office Skills, marking a success rate of 80%. students. The apprenticeship training scheme allows students to work to earn some income as they continue their education at ITE. The tours will help teachers to gain a better understanding of the career prospects of ITE students.
